options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Guest lectures from various experts
The mode of the class was a virtual, seminar format.
Occasional live guest lectures
n/a
NA

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about the Near Eastern literary tradition.  I also became a better writer.
The course helped me develop skills in close-reading and literary writing. Through in-depth discussions about different works of literature, I was able to better analyze the writings.
I learned and practiced the technique of close reading!

Working knowledge of the critical, foundational texts which comprises the bedrock for Western civilization's study of the Ancient Near East
Critical reading and writing assignments with a HEAVY stress on close readings
Refined argumentative papers with proper structure, grammar, and lines of reasoning engaging the text
Cross-text analysis and creative license for identifying Ancient Near Eastern themes, tropes, and literary devices
Literary analysis
This course was an introduction to seminal texts from the Near East that provided an interesting counterpoint to texts from the Western canon that Yale students are generally exposed to

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We read good stuff, and we read a manageable amount of stuff.  I enjoyed the assignments, and the seminars went well given the circumstances.  I enjoyed the student-led seminars toward the end of the semester.  My only issue had to do with feedback on weekly assignment, but that was more a technological problem than a pedagogical one.

The course was very well taught and the professor prioritized flexibility during a very uncertain time, which proved to be very beneficial for student learning. The strengths of the course lie in the group discussions.

Strength: Very interesting reading selection and class discussions were always very rich. General format of how a class went was effective for close engagement with the material. Weakness: The class structure changed significantly from the syllabus, so it was a bit confusing understanding what to expect from the class

Strengths: 
Broad but specific reading list, fitting for a preliminary literary immersion in a new culture's tradition
Flexible assignments which realizes the current constraints of a pandemic both physically and psychologically 
Outstanding professor who offers guidance for students of all backgrounds

Weaknesses: 
Expects refined paper-writing skills past DS-level exposure
Can be spontaneous without much notice or direction re: assignments, syllabus changes, and due dates
As good as covid learning gets

Strengths - the texts themselves, Professor Slanski was a great lecturer, the guest speakers were excellent

Weaknesses - often the way we approached texts could be a little disorganised. We could spend more time on each novel.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked using breakout rooms.
The professor was very flexible and receptive to student feedback, facilitating a low-stress learning environment.

Breakout rooms were very effective ways to have different, in-depth conversations. Having an online exhibit as a final project, while a bit confusing, worked well to replace the normal in person exhibit.

Virtual exhibit, close readings, guest lectures, and flexible scheduling all helped
Spontaneity and lack of defined class structure did not help
Use of breakout rooms was very effective in facilitating smaller group discussion

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes.  It's a literature that most people haven't read but is nevertheless very good.  Prof Slanksi is also very good.
I would absolutely recommend this course to other students. It was very engaging and the readings were incredible. I think this class would be great for students of all majors.
Yes! Professor Slanski is a wonderful person to learn under and it is a good opportunity to learn ways to engage with literature and art from different time periods in meaningful ways.

Absolutely! It's a great crash course to ancient near eastern literature (something other than the typical Western canon which gets a great deal of attention) and highly relevant to Western culture, its advocates and critics. The course reading selection is manageable and offers a great buffet of types of literature and the content is engaging. Professor Slanski is one of my favorite professors at Yale and truly invests in her students and their learning experience. Can't recommend this course enough
Yes provided theyre interested in subject matter
Yes!!! Professor Slanski is brilliant and I would constantly be thinking of our class discussions even after class had ended.
Yes, especially if you are interested in literature outside of the Western canon or want to take a literature class at Yale that improves your close reading and close looking skills

Absolutely. It's very enjoyable. You learn about a topic you might not know a lot about. As a stem major, it was a very nice change of pace as it provided a welcoming environment to relax and discuss and imagine more abstract ideas and (for me) new topics.
